channel.title: Posts on Shan Jing
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Shan Jing

item.title: Rail attacks at Paris Olympics highlight security vulnerabilities in the Eurasian rail freight network
item.description: Today’s society relies heavily on the continuous and reliable functioning of infrastructure systems such as telecommunications, electric power, gas and oil, water supply, and transportation. These systems are so essential that any interruption in their services can have crippling effects on citizens’ well-being, the nation’s economy, and society as a whole. Critical infrastructure is vulnerable to various threats, including natural hazards, component aging, increased demand, climate change, sabotage, and cascading failures due to their interdependencies.

item.title: sssThe seven levels of artificial intelligence
item.description: Author: Warren B. Powell Professor Emeritus, Princeton University There are now countless articles breathlessly talking about “AI,” the vast majority of which are talking about a very specific form of AI which is some form of machine learning (mostly pattern recognition) being performed using neural networks. This is hardly the only form of artificial intelligence, and it is far from even being the most advanced form. In addition, there are breathless articles of advanced intelligence which I claim are pure science fiction.

item.title: The seven levels of artificial intelligence

In addition, there are breathless articles of advanced intelligence which I claim are pure science fiction.

item.title: 𝐄𝐧𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐆𝐥𝐨𝐛𝐚𝐥 𝐒𝐮𝐩𝐩𝐥𝐲 𝐂𝐡𝐚𝐢𝐧 𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐫𝐨𝐮𝐠𝐡 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐄𝐮𝐫𝐚𝐬𝐢𝐚𝐧 𝐌𝐢𝐝𝐝𝐥𝐞 𝐂𝐨𝐫𝐫𝐢𝐝𝐨𝐫
item.description: The current Red Sea crisis poses significant disruptions to global supply chain resilience. In response, the Middle Corridor, also known as the Trans-Caspian International Transport Route (TITR), is gaining momentum. This route integrates multimodal transport modes, including rail and sea, connecting Chinese and European markets via Central Asia and the South Caucasus1. The current Red Sea crisis poses significant disruptions to global supply chain resilience. In response, the Middle Corridor, also known as the Trans-Caspian International Transport Route (TITR), is gaining momentum.
